conclusion: Principles of shadow formation depend on angle and distance of light source relative to object and surface.
Objects are a cigarette pack with a cigarette, an egg, a blue alarm clock, and a scorpion-like object.
Shadows A, B, C, and D correspond to cigarette pack with cigarette, egg, alarm clock, and scorpion-like object respectively.
Current light source is positioned to the left of the objects, inferred from shadows extending to the right and downward.
Shadows are elongated and stretched to the right, indicating light source is at a low angle from the left.
Size of each shadow depends on object's height and angle of light; taller objects or those closer to light source cast larger shadows.
When light source moves to the right, directly above objects, shadows will be cast directly beneath each object.
Position of shadows will shift from right side of objects to directly under them, aligning with vertical projection of each object's base.
Size of shadows will decrease because light is no longer at an oblique angle; shadows cast by overhead light are typically same size as object's base.
Shadow A will shift to directly under cigarette pack and cigarette, size will decrease to approximately base area.
Shadow B will move to directly under egg, size will reduce to egg's base diameter.
Shadow C will shift to directly under alarm clock, size will decrease to clock's base area.
Shadow D will move to directly under scorpion-like object, size will reduce to scorpion's base area.
Ground has cracks, but these do not affect shadow formation significantly unless they cast their own shadows.
Objects' heights will influence slight spread of shadows due to light source's size, but effect will be minimal with light directly above.
All shadows will move from current positions to directly beneath objects.
All shadows will shrink to sizes approximating base areas of respective objects.
Final answer: Shadows will shift to directly under objects and decrease in size to base areas.
